channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Love independent music? Hipster not a dirty word to you? Drive forward independent music with Perl.
item.description: "Small team with a startup-ish feel, even though weâ€™ve been around for an age. Weâ€™re not VC funded, weâ€™re in this for the long-haul - we want to make a difference. Strongly motivated to ensure that artists and labels are getting a fair deal. We all love music, occasionally the office will host a (fairly niche) gig downstairs."

item.title: A role to give Perl Developers a warm glow... and powdered snow
item.description: Youâ€™ll be working for a company whose whole ethos is based around increasing fundraising for good causes, and youâ€™ll be directly helping them achieve this with the work you do on their platform - giving supporters of non-profit organizations the tools to raise funds on their behalf.

item.title: Come be a Perl developer in the smartest city in the USA
item.description: We need another great Perl developer to add to the team. You know your code, you need minimal direction and you do your work with a smile, because you enjoy it. We want the kind of person who can figure out how something works just by reading the code and when they see something is broken, they roll up their sleeves and fix it without having to be told to do it.

item.title: Modern Perl developers needed to drive medical diagnosis into the future
item.description: A Cambridge-based provider of a revolutionary diagnostic tool for clinicians is looking for Modern Perl developers who are passionate about using their tech skills to help further the field of medicine. Youâ€™ll be building the tools that scientists are using to cure disease.

item.title: Namaste and a Beach Day - Perl Position in California
item.description: Our client is looking for a Perl programmer who wants to tame the job jungle for employers and employees through their candidate sourcing and data management products. We know what youâ€™re thinking: When every day is a California postcard, who needs a vacation?

Time Theft: How Hidden and Unplanned work Commit the Perfect Crime
item.description: The five sources of unaccounted work. How to make our work and the time we spend on it visible. How to eliminate the waste and become much more productive.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 014
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 015
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. We now pick one random member as winner from the list of participated members every week. You can increase your chance to win the prize money of $50 Amazaon voucher by submitting solutions to all the challenges as well as blog about it. The Weekly prize money is kindly sponsored by Peter Sergeant of PerlCareers. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - Story so far ...
item.description: Read about the journey of Perl Weekly Challenge on the occassion of completing 3 months.

item.title: TPC:iP Thank You for Coming
item.description: The organizers of TPCiP want to thank all who attended, volunteered, presented, or sponsored us! Even if you are just following along on Twitter or subscribed to our YouTube channel - thanks for supporting Perl!

item.title: diff-so-fancy v1.2.6
item.description: diff-so-fancy strives to make your diffs human readable instead of machine readable. This helps improve code quality and helps you spot defects faster.

item.title: Additional Perl Weekly Challenge 14
item.description: Neil Bowers proposed additional challenge for the Perl Weekly Challenge.

item.title: Simplicity made easy
item.description: Damian insights into the Perl Weekly Challenge has been greatly appreciated and discussed. You wouldn't want to miss his points here.

item.title: Get premium custom name badges for your team at StickerYou.com
item.description: StickerYou doesnâ€™t only allow you to make custom stickers for your business. You can also brand your staff with custom name badges. Itâ€™s an easy way to tie it all together, amplifying your brand identity and letting your customers know youâ€™re there to help them. StickerYou.com allows you to order any size, shape and quantity. Most companies will only sell to you if you buy at least 100. Whoa. Not cool. What are you waiting for? Get your team better name badges! Use code PERL10 at checkout for an exclusive Perl Weekly discount.

item.title: #414 - Do you want to learn Test Automation using Perl?
item.description:
Hi there!

Perl Maven is known for best collection of articles. Recently I came across one such, "Test Automation using Perl screencasts". If you want to learn more about it then I would highly recommend it. For more information, please visit page.

Please do let us know how you find it, till then enjoy the week.
